section.text: Hi, good morning. I was wondering, good morning, I was wondering can you talk about what your assumptions are for deposit betas in your NIM guidance for next quarter because it looks like, you know, even with the 75 basis point increase in the Fed funds rate in November and significantly higher average Fed funds rate next quarter versus the prior quarter, I think you guided your NIM rising only 25 basis points or so. So I guess the question is what are you baking in for deposit betas and is there some element of conservatism embedded in there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Manan Gosalia", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "efb2bf95-278a-472b-9444-3bab461b3122", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: As you know Manan we do like to provide conservative guidance and that 3.15% admittedly is somewhat conservative it's only factoring in the November increase and the markets obviously expecting a December increase as well and so SOFR tends to lead those type of increases as we saw last quarter so we have 50 basis point sequential increase two quarters ago in the NIM, 40 basis points this quarter and we're guiding 25 basis points but certainly it could be higher than that going forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c3728379-73a4-4a09-b92c-f0621ea9b992", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: We were expecting deposit beta as rates kind of continued to increase to get closer to 50%. On the last incremental increase for us it was 35% and cumulatively it was 25%, and we've been really leading most of the industry focusing on clients and sharing and being generous with clients as the rates have increased. And so going forward 50% frankly might be too conservative as well just because of when you look at competitors, we're certainly well ahead of competitors -- most of our competitors on the sweep rates.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "c3728379-73a4-4a09-b92c-f0621ea9b992", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Got it. And then on third-party bank deposits, we saw through this earning season that many banks are relying more on wholesale funding. So I guess the question is, what are you seeing in terms of demand from third-party banks and where should we expect the third-party bank fee rate to go if the Fed stabilizes at 4.5%? And is there a possibility that you're able to earn a higher spread on those deposits as you renegotiate your contracts next year than the typical, I think Fed funds plus 12.5 basis points or so that you typically earn?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Manan Gosalia", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "8b8118b7-ef84-41f2-9429-ed4100d761e1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Yeah, I think absolutely the demand is way up. And as you pointed out, if you look at almost all of our competitors, if you really looked at just what's happened to cash sweeps, we're all in the same ballpark, it's just most of the other firms have gone into high yield savings to supplement their cash or to money market sweeps, so we haven't done that. So we may, but to date, we feel like we have ample low-cost funding with our sweeps and we do see the demand going up which will impact rates and Paul, I'll let you to address the rate dynamic.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "fe0be284-30da-4208-8803-3d569b8150da", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yeah. I mean at the trough in the last year or so the demand from third-party banks was obviously very weak and the pricing was kind of in that Fed funds effective range, which was down 20 basis points or so from the peak spreads a couple of years prior. So we are quickly seeing that demand resume that's the first step and now we're starting to see prices and the economics improve on the spread. But again 20 basis point spread improvement, if that's sort of the potential to get back to the last kind of peak spread two years ago, pales in comparison to the base rate improvement that we get from the Federal Reserve on those balances, so net-net a significant tailwind though on those balances.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "54cc7961-9e67-4cdc-969a-6ed820e94f8f", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: So it sounds like in terms of the fee rate, you could be well above the 2 percentage points or so that you peaked up during the prior cycle, so if we compare the end of this rate hike cycle should we expect a fee rate above the 2 percentage points that you saw last cycle?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Manan Gosalia", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "58d5b6e7-6a56-4723-8e71-20cb9a636a93", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Yeah. I mean, we're already guiding just for this upcoming quarter to 2.5% as an example.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "76bb998f-ca7f-4833-9c0d-25ac4379cc9c", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: All right. Perfect. Thank you. Thank you very much. We'll proceed with the next question on the line from Gerry O'Hara with Jefferies. Go right ahead.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Manan Gosalia", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "4e20dbea-1051-4f2d-95e7-1d5b380bb2a6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Great. Thanks. Perhaps just a little bit of context or color on the advisor recruiting market. I know it's obviously been another kind of challenging quarter from a volatility standpoint. So would just love to get a little bit of color as to what you're seeing industry-wide in terms of those dynamics.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gerry O'Hara", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "28ee9cf8-64d3-4fef-8d74-282d4da183d2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Yeah. I think I've been now what dozen years in this job and everybody always asks me the recruiting. Market seems to be getting more competitive. So my response, it's kind of always been competitive and we've been on a good role. So, we still see it as very active. We -- even in '09 we thought recruiting our best year would go off because of the great dislocation, but it was actually resulted in our best couple of years until the recent few years.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "4dc4a2ed-8c8d-48cd-9a29-dcb720995182", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: So, it's still very active, it's very competitive and continues to be such. But as you can see with our kind of 400 advisors added this year if you adjust for the RIA channel, the people that moved our advisor account, we've had another very, very strong year. And really the largest teams we've ever recruited continue to come in and so the average is going up also, not just market but just traction of our platform for high-net-worth and ultra-high-net-worth advisors as well as the advisors that we've recruited for throughout our history. So we're still -- still a big part of our strategy, we think that will still be strong backlog is strong and probably won't last forever. But it looks pretty good in the short-to-mid term. Fair enough. And then perhaps one for Paul Shoukry. Can you maybe just comment a little bit, we obviously saw an increase from 2Q to 3Q on the non-comp side of expenses, that actually came off a little bit in 4Q but can you perhaps maybe help us think a little bit about how that kind of run-rate might look going into the next couple of quarters?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "4dc4a2ed-8c8d-48cd-9a29-dcb720995182", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yeah. Gerry, most of the sequential increase was really attributable to having a full quarter of results for both TriState Capital and SumRidge, which sequentially added about $25 million of non-compensation expenses, so that was the primary driver of the sequential increase which we expected. Looking-forward, I think if you look at this quarter as a baseline and I think it was around $410 million of non-compensation expenses when you adjust out for the loan loss provision and for some of the acquisition-related expenses that we break out in our non-GAAP schedule.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "b787d5c4-8d5d-405d-88c5-f025c797f798", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: And looking-forward, I would say that would be, you know, potentially our best guess right now for fiscal 2023 is that number totaling around $1.7 billion in fiscal '23, which of the $410 million base represents somewhere around 1.5% growth sequentially each quarter in '23. And most of that growth will really be coming from our technology investments. We're still heavily investing in technology to support advisors, their clients and really all the businesses and functions across the firm so that's going to continue to be a significant focus for us going forward. And then you're going to see kind of on a year-over-year basis growth in business development expenses as the first half of fiscal '22 travel and conferences obviously were still suppressed by the COVID pandemic, so you'll see that normalize for the full year in fiscal '23.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "b787d5c4-8d5d-405d-88c5-f025c797f798", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Okay. Great. Thanks for taking my questions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gerry O'Hara", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "7cfd68ce-f447-4731-9b2c-0419e9f77476", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Hey, guys good morning, thanks for the question. So maybe first just focusing on some of the bank dynamics. I guess, if we look at the last cycle, bank NIM peaked at around 3.5% and not to pinpoint you joining specific quarter. But I guess when you zoom out a little bit in taking your conservative posture on the deposit betas but it doesn't sound like they're going up about [Phonetic] 50%. If you think about TriState now in the mix that's more loan-heavy, so obviously higher yielding and the absolute level of rates is higher. So, should we be thinking closer to 4% bank NIM once the Fed has done or how are you thinking about that sort of run rate on the other end of that cycle?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Blostein", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "4e5d9537-4c48-432d-9f9c-6330c1b2c133", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yeah, there's a lot of moving parts. I would say one of the difference is now versus in the last cycle is that our concentration of securities based loans are higher. Now that has a -- typically has a lower NIM associated with it because they're fully collateralized with liquid marketable securities, so the risk-adjusted returns are very attractive. But, typically a lower NIM through cycles relative to corporate loans. And so there's a lot of moving parts there, I think just like I shared with Manan on the BDP fees. I think this time around, I mean, rates are expected to be higher than they were last cycle just the base rates. And so given the loan mix, higher rates, a lot of different variables. But I don't think we can call 3.5% necessarily a ceiling, but I don't think we're also ready to say that it could achieve 4% either, I think we need to kind of see where cash sorting and cost deposit trends play out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "fd9be8d8-8d66-4fa2-9bf2-732b661a543b", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Got it. Fair enough. Just staying on the balance sheet theme for a minute. You guys obviously you had the right call on not extending duration a year or two ago and keeping the balance sheet fairly floating. But if you look at what's going on today, security yields are quite attractive and maybe there's a little bit more upside but that's a fairly good return on invested capital as you kind of look what the market rates are today. What are your thoughts about building securities portfolio from here, maybe extending duration a little bit just to lock-in what looks like a pretty attractive rates of return?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Blostein", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "917597ea-ba6e-4c88-be00-e2d3ca39a584", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yeah. So we're not against the securities portfolio, but our first thing is to fund our growth in loans and securities becomes the next part of it. So, we agree they're attractive, after being beat-up for not locking in rates over a number of years, we're not after waiting it out and now having the balance sheet, we're not ready to call that we've reached peak rates and start locking in. So, I think at least in the near-term we're going to be flexible as the Fed probably has a couple of rate hikes and then we'll look at it, things settle down we may balance in a little more. But our first funding is for growth and then any excess funding which we're certainly happy to put in securities, because you're right, we have very good spread right now.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "4646b3b4-3a36-46ff-8714-0f65040e9c28", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: I think kind of looking forward we really built-up the securities portfolio in the last couple of years there is -- there's no, there's very little third-party bank demand so we kind of brought onto the balance sheet as an accommodation. But now with the cash sorting dynamics with loan growth being solid, we would expect some of that buildup in securities to really run-off over the next year to fund that loan growth that Paul talked about.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "d3279ea1-0d9e-4473-b096-31bec3b5944c", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Some of that loan growth has duration as well. I mean so you saw the mortgage portfolio grew sequentially during the quarter pretty nicely. There's duration obviously associated with that portfolio that gives us that same type of protection. But to the extent that we take duration, our preference has been to take it to support client relationships. And to the extent that we have excess kind of cash beyond the loan growth and we would certainly investment in securities because it is a good return as if the cash we sweep bought third-party banks as well, so right now we have a lot of different options and that's just the power of the flexibility that we have with the cash balances and the flexibility that we preserve frankly through the last couple of years.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "d3279ea1-0d9e-4473-b096-31bec3b5944c", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Got it. All right. Thanks. I won't ask the pretax margin question just to remind there was a plus at the guidance next to 20 when you guys gave it last-time I just wanted to make sure that, it's still there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Blostein", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "9532ebcf-2eb6-4e4d-8cd4-7e40bb3e82c1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yes, it was over 20.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "f9c4912b-2ccd-4e9b-8937-f91b6c46e734", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: I told you so.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "ca9ac964-a134-41d4-b832-251ea548efac", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Hi, good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Chubak", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "976308db-0883-46ca-9173-051c23308704", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Hi, Steve.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "4064815a-280e-4536-8bf2-efdc415f130a", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: So wanted to start with the question on FICC. You alluded Paul the some of the headwinds to the business, it's been run rating the last couple of quarters at about $100 million. This most recent quarter, you noted it included SumRidge Partners' contribution as well. As the Fed continues to remove excess liquidity from the system, do you anticipate further pressure on this $100 million baseline, or is that a fair run rate that we can underwrite looking out to next year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Chubak", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "8d3503d5-f612-4750-9a50-ee070f7e99ec", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: You can see the dynamic, they have a great fixed income franchise but really in the -- in that banking space, it's very, very strong and they are focused on the same dynamics, the whole industry is. So as cash tightens, they're going to fund loans first and security second, just like us. So, yeah that could have pressure.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "bbb3c799-3494-48c4-8b8a-61acd5260d76", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Now there's other parts of the business that will certainly have pressure on that run rates if it gets tighter and again the other hand SumRidge is, maybe timing is everything but this is kind of the perfect market for them to perform. They are just and really killing it right now but everything's in their favor but everything is a headwind for that banking part of the franchise that we're so good at. So it could come under more pressure also.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "bbb3c799-3494-48c4-8b8a-61acd5260d76", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Great. Just for my follow-up, maybe on the comp ratio. Certainly, a nice positive surprise especially relative to the guidance. I understand, Paul and can appreciate your reluctance to update the 19% to 20% plus margin target. But wanted to get a sense as to how we should think about your philosophy around comp given so much of the revenue growth is going to come from less compensable areas. What's a reasonable expectation for where the comp rate should be running if rates stay higher for longer?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Chubak", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "bc4a049a-e5cf-4ee3-aff4-532d1c23d545", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Well, where we have been even with our advisors and associates we paid them, we think it's fairly on their production and we haven't paid on interest. Now interest went away, we didn't change their payouts and comp obviously it affects management's comp. So our plan right now is the interest rates will continue to be non-compensable and so certainly impact some of the bank comp, but generally, to the extent, there is more interest spread and margin comp will go down to the extent that normalizes it goes the other way, the ratio will go up. There's no change fundamentally on how we're paying based on it, so again interest spreads will drive it down for a period of time. I think spreads right now are like in any cycle probably outsized for -- I don't know if they're out how long that stays year, two years, quarter, but it will return, but our comp philosophy is the same so you should see improvement as spreads -- as interest spreads improve.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "0e85d29f-b537-4875-8ca1-09e3094d4d35", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yeah, I think the one thing I would add is the compensation philosophy kind of from outside of the sort of advisor force that Paul was talking about was to help to share the success of the firm with our associates and we are in a high inflation environment and so whereas we're entering the year-end, we are leading into being generous to our associates and sharing in the success with our associates just as we always do. And so those year-end increases won't really be reflected until the second fiscal quarter -- the first calendar quarter of the fiscal year and that's when payroll taxes reset of course. But as Paul said, the interest spreads have been a significant benefit to our compensation ratio down to this kind of 62% range.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "5f7682d3-2574-46d3-8403-e17e62b71449", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Okay. And anything on the admin cost side that we need to be mindful of? I do think the admin comp was running a little bit higher than we had anticipated or at least based on what some of the napkin math would suggest when you try to back out some of the non-compensable portions of revenue?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Chubak", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "393ef8e4-2781-4b51-97f4-f7befd9fa120", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Again, that reflects the full quarter of results from both TriState Capital and SumRidge. So I think this baseline going forward is a good baseline to start-off with. But again we will increase salaries across the Board and we're leaning into being generous with that given the competitive labor environment, the inflationary pressures and the success that we're having as a firm. So we really want to share that success with the associates who made it all possible. And that again -- and we're also continuing to hire in all of our businesses to support and continue the great growth that we've had across our businesses and so that would really be reflected throughout fiscal '23.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "01dc4fc7-ec75-4f1d-84c0-9882545a82df", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Helpful color. Thanks for taking my questions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steven Chubak", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "18978d4a-5410-4f6d-ac2f-298b8efd87e4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Jim, are you there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "77556e15-05da-41b7-81af-9d2b7a8dbee9", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Hello, can you hear me?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jim Mitchell", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "258fdb39-2292-47e1-bf17-ae8014c6dda5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global"}

section.text: I can hear you now.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "fb224efc-efa8-4d50-81bb-28ad1af4a6a7", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Okay, sorry. So deposits are down to about 6% of client assets based on sort of the guidance for October by client cash, I should say. Can you remind us of the historical average for cash levels, may be a low and high range? Just trying to think through where that starts to bottom out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jim Mitchell", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "1c4b3809-8efb-4e00-9d9e-ad552c7bcf9e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global"}

section.text: It's a pretty wide range. I think the peak of that range was in the mid-teens in 2009, but of course, that is because cash increase and markets decreased substantially. But I would say the trough was somewhere in that 5% range maybe a little lower than 5% in 2019. So to your point we're at 6%, I think the 25 year historical average is probably in the 7% to 8% range, so it's a pretty wide range.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "fc87ee65-35e3-4702-9b8e-53586f1d4743", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Right. And is there a point where you have to more aggressively defend cash balances and deposits to fund the balance sheet?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jim Mitchell", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "296828c6-9073-43fd-ab2e-c6ebf06c80b7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global"}

section.text: Yeah, absolutely. I mean, if they get -- right now, we've been fortunate and have managed it well as you know we've been focused on a flexible balance sheet. But you need cash to operate the business, so if you see runs, we've talked about even offering high rate savings and others we just haven't implemented it, haven't felt like we need to but if we see cash into levels that concern us we will do that. We also have TriState now who is a very good source of funding. They've got a very strong net funding operation, which is one of the reasons for the acquisition which I don't think few understood, say so much cash why would you have it? And I think it was a year ago we were talking about our concern about cash in the future. So it's a -- so we've got alternatives now, but absolutely you need cash to run this business and you want to be able to service your client cash. And at some point, we looked at our cash balances, they haven't left the system, it's gone more into fixed-income or money markets on our platform. So they're still in the system. We just haven't kept them into a pure cash form.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "c07dd414-f8be-4d62-a268-9554cde719d7", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Great. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jim Mitchell", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "73f04290-7cc5-4c04-9a46-b569ea0bc015", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Seaport Global"}

section.text: Hey good morning guys. How are you?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Devin Ryan", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "5f101ed4-b2cc-491c-adee-9ac98012ec1d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JMP Securities"}

section.text: Good, Devin.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "6b04fb90-7379-4afd-9c56-7e7f03ba6779", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Good. Most questions have been asked. Want to come back to the balance sheet a bit here and just think about your mix and maybe follow-up on Alex's question. Just deposits obviously becoming more scarce here. And so when you think about the mix moving forward, are there beyond you may be thinking about the securities book, are there other areas maybe in the loan book or just more broadly where there's room for optimization and maybe areas to drive the risk-adjusted NIM higher from here all else equal.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Devin Ryan", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "71a5629c-c788-44b7-99ec-363a5ddd2202", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JMP Securities"}

section.text: Well, there probably always is. So part of what we're doing as we're going through our budgeting exercise is to say where do we want to deploy capital. We've got up with the banking business, a broader bank business, TriState is an independent business with its third-party platforms. And the question is between that and Raymond James Bank where do you allocate capital in the portfolio really to optimize not, you know, partly the balance sheet from our standpoint, but really to allow freedom for example for TriState to service their customers. So we're going through that to make sure that the capital allocations makes sense both for those businesses and for us. So there always is periods of rapid transition right now it's a little bit harder to do it but we're in a lot of discussion on it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "4285cc5e-de9e-403a-adfd-ba93227b1487", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: I would say, just to reinforce that we really don't manage the balance sheet allocation to necessarily maximize NIM. We do it to maximize risk adjusted returns and we believe that securities based loans both at Raymond James Bank to our own clients and TriState Capital to their independent clients is the best risk adjusted return. So that is kind of the priority to the extent that the demand is there and which we think that over time, that just continues to be a big tailwind for us. And then we look at the other loan categories, we like the mix that we have right now with 35% of our loans and securities based loans. So that's kind of how we're thinking about it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "254be6a2-ce44-4c8b-b8db-1bc763417c6f", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Yeah. Okay. Thanks, Paul. And then a follow-up here just want to talk a little bit about the investment banking outlook. Appreciate there's always a little bit of crystal ball in there and you guys are going to [Indecipherable] conservatism, just given the uncertainty in the market. But just want to make sure I understand how you're thinking about it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Devin Ryan", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "10ccd1fb-618b-49c9-a9a2-8392583f16fb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JMP Securities"}

section.text: You have equity issuances is going to be market-centric but market-stabilize that probably would improve and then your M&A business is structurally larger, so all else equal that the business trajectory over time is higher. In fixed-income, it feels like maybe could remain a bit under pressure if rates remain higher, so just trying to think about how much of maybe this more muted near-term outlook is just purely market-centric versus maybe the side would be maybe every business doesn't snap-back to where it was over the last year or two because rates are higher or are there some other structural dynamic in the market has changed. So I just wanted to kind of parse through both the cyclical versus anything that maybe a little bit more impaired for a continued period.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Devin Ryan", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "10ccd1fb-618b-49c9-a9a2-8392583f16fb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JMP Securities"}

section.text: I think if you look at, I'll go in reverse order in the fixed-income business. I mean the challenge for traditional fixed-income business in a rising rate market is when do people invest kind of in the long-term and that will happen as rates come up. I think that that business will do well. People have been buying shorter-term as they start buying longer-term it's more profitable for us too and but you got to get rates to a point where people think rates are there to really start doing that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "a05ee05d-f808-4680-80cb-0359c44e60b3", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: And certainly the increase in rates will help, but we're just at a pause really feel that happens. So I think that's more timing. M&A is a little harder. Backlogs good, clients are good, even now, right now it's up for us and it's up in Europe for the industry. And if you look at European dynamics with rates and inflation everything, you go well how could that be. So, I mean there's still cash, there's still strategic investors. And our growth on our platform and who we've added and we're continuing to grow it we believe in it, but that one is harder to predict. I mean it's been stronger. I think the most people had predicted.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "a05ee05d-f808-4680-80cb-0359c44e60b3", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: The backlog is still strong, but when people close or not or when that stops it's just, that's a tough one. So when you come off over the last two years, with almost unprecedented M&A is that a baseline or is that a peak forever, which it probably isn't. But, again we still very, very high on that business. But that was kind of hard to say what triggers it to continue or what triggers it to slowdown or stop for a while.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "a05ee05d-f808-4680-80cb-0359c44e60b3", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Okay. All right. Thanks very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Devin Ryan", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "3b201bf8-2335-48ee-acd1-2e73f600eff9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JMP Securities"}

section.text: Hi, good morning. So just given the level of sorting right now and the pressure that may put on total available funding as you look out a couple of years, just completely understand the cautiousness and the tone around the size of the AFS book and maybe letting some of that runoff in order to support loan growth. So just two follow-ups on that. What is the current duration of the AFS portfolio? And how much of that portfolio would run off per year if you didn't reinvest at all in the portfolio? And can you also remind us, are there specific minimums that you need to hold in terms of the CIP and the third-party bank sweep just so we have that as the sorting process continues here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kyle Voigt", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "81b771d7-1f51-4d83-868d-2da794039df8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: I'd say in the securities portfolio, the average duration is somewhere around four years now with the securities portfolio. So if you think about kind of a normal distribution, you might have somewhere around 20% to 25% runoff a year, probably back-end loaded a little bit. But -- and again, we're going to use a lot of that to fund the loan growth as the current plans. There is a baseline for CIP of cash balances there. If you kind of look back at 2019, I think there's probably $2.5 billion or $3 billion of cash there for a variety of reasons. And so maybe that's kind of a good way to think about the floor there for those balances. And really, with BDP, that's a function of providing clients FDIC insurance, trying to maximize their FDIC coverage as much as we possibly can, given all the constraints and the demand from third-party banks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "050f4f15-1c10-467b-9b16-98267f43c092", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: And so is there -- I guess, given your clients' allocation and then you have a certain number of charters that you can provide FDIC insurance with yourself. So is there a certain amount of minimum there, I guess on the third-party bank side? Is it a few billion dollars that needs to be held there or is it some number that's smaller than that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kyle Voigt", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "7b23e4c5-8f6b-491c-97ae-b498785a53ae", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Really, the way we think about the minimum on the BDP balances is essentially providing some level of funding buffer. We don't want to overextend the funding as we've seen in the industry, it's challenging when you overextend the funding to your own banks, and you don't have a buffer there, and one of the things that we're thinking through is what do we want that buffer to be. Now our balance sheet is much more liquid than it used to be 10 years ago when we established the 50% buffer that some of you are aware of. So we think that's much too conservative. But we're kind of currently -- now that we've completed the acquisition of TriState Capital understanding their balance sheet, we're currently in the midst of determining what the appropriate buffer is, but we're going to, just as we always do, air on the side of conservatism there as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Shoukry", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "711ade64-6742-4ef0-b227-5fd63d9c53ef", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Understood. That's really helpful. And I just have one follow-up related to administrative comp. I think on last quarter's call, you mentioned there was an off-cycle bonus paid in the fiscal third quarter, which caused the PCG segment admin comp to be elevated. But we saw another $15 million sequential increase in that PCG admin comp line in the fiscal fourth quarter. So just wondering what drove that and how much of that is onetime in nature, if at all.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kyle Voigt", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "f2a691fa-3cf6-4ff6-966a-c3d82b801353", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: I'm not sure, I think it was a 5% sequential increase. And again, that bounces around based on benefit accruals that we adjust for, particularly at the end of the fiscal year and making sure we're fully funded and accrued for on benefits and other things. So there's nothing that I could point to specifically that would describe that other than just sort of natural growth and changes to the accruals, etc.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "400c0341-7c6d-423c-b4a7-18cd79ff1925", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Okay, understood. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kyle Voigt", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "93923b68-7944-405f-a046-5e01077b4cdc", "speaker_title": "Analyst at KBW"}

section.text: Good morning. This is Michael Kelly on for Bill. Thank you for taking my question. Most questions have been asked but I did have one follow-up on the loan mix. Paul and Paul, are you seeing any shift in demand for the SBL. It look I got to end of the period basis they dipped a little bit. The resi was pretty resilient. But are you seeing any shift in demand with higher interest rate environment that we should be worried about near term. I understand your long-term outlook is quite positive for the balance sheet.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Kelly", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "8e5168b4-7f23-4c33-bdd1-7d38510b34a7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: I think that -- yeah, some of that SBL was really -- a lot of people use that as GAAP funding, so part of the mortgage demand where people went from SBL, you know, paid those off and as mortgage homes and other things. So we think the demand is there, not only is there for our clients, TriState is growing their market share with new relationships who has a huge opportunity. So I think SBL is over time still even short-term and longer-term, so very, very positive. The question becomes as the rates continue to go up when was that really cheap source of funding maybe not people are less likely to borrow, but I still think that business is doing well. So I think you see a blip -- saw a blip this quarter really on that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "8bbb9f6c-b9b0-496b-b611-7de4ac326d78", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Great. Thanks. And then if I just had one more follow-up as a percentage of AUA you still are -- the SBL as a percentage of AUA behind some of your wirehouse peers do you see that gap closing over time?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Kelly", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "6352a671-48e0-46d7-b4c7-35bb4e926a3e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: We've just never been as aggressive in pushing debt through our organization. I mean that -- so our products, SBL is even a relatively new product for us compared to our competitors. So -- and we certainly don't have quotas for anyone to present it or require them to present or even branch managers with quotas. So because of that, our debt concentration historically has been lower than certainly our wirehouse competitors. And we continue to gain share, but we do it more through natural means and the advisor really has to initiate that versus us going out and pushing it or selling it to advisors. So -- but our content -- it's going up, but we're just not progressive and that haven't been. It's just part of the culture for a long time. Great. Thank you. Makes sense.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "1bdbcbff-846e-42ef-b263-ea710c51b7ce", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: Well, great. I appreciate everybody being on the call. And although very strong end of the year, it's an environment outside of the equity markets and interest rates and cash sorting and everything else that's hard to call. We're still -- that's when we really appreciate the flexibility we have in the balance sheet and our capital base and everything else to be able to navigate. So optimistic about the future, don't know what's going to happen as you get GDP and you get people still raising rates and inflation, it's going to be an interesting quarter -- a couple of quarters, but that's when you can see that our advisors are still -- clients say 97% satisfied with our advisors is a pretty high rate, and they need them more now than ever.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "ec24cc85-2338-4cd9-ae36-8c2ded229adf", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

section.text: So with that, appreciate your time, and we'll talk to you soon.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Paul C. Reilly", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "ec24cc85-2338-4cd9-ae36-8c2ded229adf", "speaker_title": "Chair and Chief Executive Officer at Raymond James"}

title: Q&A for RJF (Raymond James) on 10/27/22 8:15 AM ET
